content: 100 questions answered you think I can do it I think I can do it
hey guys welcome back to black magic
crafts I did not build anything last week for two days video I took a few
days off took my family camping and relaxed a little bit and also this
coming weekend tomorrow if you're watching this video on Friday is fan
quest it is a convention here in Winnipeg and on Sunday I will be there
doing a few panels and meet-and-greets and all that kind of fun stuff so I just
simply didn't have time to build anything so I'm doing everybody's
favorite youtuber cop-out and doing a Q&A for today's video so I put up on the
community tab on YouTube and Facebook asking for you guys to give me your
questions so that I could answer them I got like 500 questions so I'm not
gonna answer 500 questions luckily a lot of them overlap there's a lot of people
who asked variations of the same question so that's great
there was also a fair amount of questions that I'm not gonna delve into
because I have answered them in fully dedicated videos like how do you use
terrain to set up a room well I have a whole video on that if you have a
question like that use the search bar in YouTube black magic craft insert thing
you're wondering about there's likely a video about it I'm also not going to
delve into some very good questions because I've already covered them
extensively in previous Q&A so I will put links down below if you want to dive
into those ones mainly my origin story I covered that extensively in the q and
A's and also in my it's okay to be a beginner video which you should check
out if you want that that one is worth the time to dig into and a lot of people
ask me about my musical background which again I've covered in detail in those
videos but just the short answer for those who don't want to delve deep I
used to be an electronic music producer I had two projects one was called
distorted memory it was an electro industrial project and the other was
called cake builder and it was a break core kind of aggressive IDM drum and
bass I will put links to the bank apps for
most of those in the video description so if you want to just go listen to them
you can do that with that out of the way I got hundred questions I broke
everything down to a hundred and I'm going to try to power through them so
that this is enjoyable to actually sit through and watch and you get your
questions answered future self you're gonna have to edit this really well I'm
also gonna kind of paraphrase some of these questions to save time so let's
start with the questions from my patrons because I'm giving them priority because
they make this channel possible speaking of prioritizing prioritizing projects
overwhelmed and not lose motivation one at a time basically how do I prioritize
what I'm doing and not lose motivation do I work on multiple things at one time
I have learned that if I put a project down I will probably never ever come
back to it whenever I have a partially completed project that I put aside to
come back to later you really sits in my way unfinished for several weeks or
months until I inevitably ditch the project and trash it so for that reason
I try to stick to one main project at a time sometimes I will be doing two
different things so that I can overlap drying times and be more efficient but
essentially my head space is in one project at a time and I try to see
things through to completion if there's something that stops me from completing
it that's beyond just picking up some materials I usually just terminate it
cuz I know it'll never get finished ever thought of working with someone to
publish some ideas as modules like my own stories and stuff yes that's
actually taking place right now kind of slowly because I've been dragging my
feet on some of my parts of the arrangement however this is something
that's going to be happening you will see a collaboration publication that's a
good like that collaboration publication for myself in days another group of
people somebody well I'll tell you it's quest givers quest givers and myself are
gonna be releasing a module that we came up with together so stay tuned for that
what stories movies literature inspires you and your
games to be honest not a lot I don't think I'm sure subconsciously one I
don't read a lot I just don't have time and now I actually have very little time
to watch movies or TV shows so the few things I do watch are really
big well heavily watched things so I'm not gonna rip off Game of Thrones for my
game because everyone will have seen it so honestly not not too much really have
you watched Letterkenny no more than a few very short clips I probably should
watch more because one of my best friends references it all the time but
I'm a bad Canadian and I haven't watched it yet when a project doesn't go as
planned whether it be a piece you're trying to build or a paint job turning
out do you repurpose that piece into something different or try to salvage as
best you can and work the rest of the piece around it to make it fit for the
most part if I have something that's going poorly I will just pivot and keep
powering through that project until I get it right I will find ways to hide
the mistakes or capitalize on those mistakes and use them as something
positive in the build and more and more I try to keep that in the videos when
they take place because it's a really important fundamental skill of any
creative process to be able to pivot from a mistake and adapt I received a
lot of questions about my tattoos and what they mean what I have how many I
have what do my wrists say so I'm just gonna kind of combine them all here I'm
not gonna go into all my tattoos but you guys mostly see the stuff on my arms
first of all we have this a lot of new stuff here that you saw outlined and
then filled in recently the colors are a lot more vibrant than the older stuff
because it hasn't settled yet for those of you who don't know too much about
tattoos but here I have a big Lich which that's hard to show this on camera got
the Lich that obviously represents my love for Dungeons & Dragons here is a
very old tattoo this is coming up on 16 years this
tattoo actually represents one of my previous musical projects distorted
memory it's kind of an adaptation of the logo here I have more skulls because I
love skulls obviously this one a skull with the ram's horn actually also
represents my other musical project cake builder intertwined with all of this are
flowers and a motif of wheat there's wheat poppies and roses running
throughout as well as some lost that is related to my heritage as a Ukrainian
Canadian wheat is very important to Ukrainians as our poppies and roses are
a common motif I come from a background of farmers my family have been farming
in Canada for over a hundred years actually fun fact the first Ukrainian
immigrant ever to set foot in Canada was a pillow PO like myself I'm still very
connected to that heritage my family still does a lot of Ukrainian things and
this is kind of my homage to that I also have a big rooster which is not finished
I have to get around to finishing that it's also related to the farming
background my wrists have some words that you've probably seen and someone
was asking what they say because they can't read them on camera these say
ultimate machine and these again are related to music my background
in industrial music my best friend for many years and myself got into this
music it was very important to us and we both got these tattoos that say ultimate
machine they are it's a title of a song from a project called suicide commando
which was very important in our formative years we have these matching
tattoos unfortunately if you've seen my other q and A's you you know that a
couple years ago I lost my best friend to suicide in a horrible sense of irony
because we had these suicide commando tattoos so now I'm the only one who has
them the the matching pair is no more but
these are serve as a reminder to that friendship and that part of my life oh
and if anyone's wondering where I get my tattoos all the work up here was done by
my friend Steve McConnell at Main Street tattoo collective and Winnipeg and
everything else here this early tattoo and all this new work was actually done
by my brother-in-law Kurt whisk um who operates a very long running shop in the
city called tattoos for the individuals so if you're gonna pay you want some
tattoos check them out when making individual bricks what size
do you tend to use for your builds I don't stick to a particular size the
important part is that the length is double the width so that you can half
offset and turn corners for bigger things like castles and ruins and
whatnot I will use a size that's around one centimeter by 1 centimeter by 2
centimeters and then for littler things I'll kind of go with like quarter inch
by quarter inch by half inch but yeah mixing the measurements there because
I'm Canadian uh-huh really doesn't doesn't matter I and I don't know why
honestly I just eyeball them and I usually just make enough for that
project so it doesn't matter if they match up to other stuff I like that
variation amongst my builds do you have any hobbies outside of crafting what do
you do for fun when you need a break from the YouTube gig it's a good
question because this hobby was my hobby now it is my job well the half the hobby
is half my job actually YouTube is the other half they go together I can't
enjoy it as a hobby anymore to be to be honest I need something else to separate
from to end my workday with sometimes it is actually playing the games but that
doesn't happen as much as I would like so currently my main hobby the way I
unwind and shutdown is by playing video games which is not very productive but
I've been really enjoying vintage gaming lately playing through a lot of the old
NES titles that I loved when I was a kid and some super nintendo stuff and really
just unwinding laying down playing some video games yeah I wish it was a more
creative thing but my work is now creative enough what
situations do you feel it's better to use the green stuff roller versus
individual bricks and for me it just comes down to time I always think that
the individual bricks look better by a long like a wide margin I much prefer
them but if you're in a hurry that's when the rollers are great I've been
getting away from using them but I'm also not pumping out a ton of repet
repetitive stuff I just build stuff for the video so speed speed is what
separates one to use what knowing your history and music do you ever create any
of them musically here in your videos or are you completely done with creating
music that's a good question the old videos the ones that had my
original intro and intro music I composed that original intro music I
never composed the stuff in the videos but the intro music I composed but
that's it now everything you hear is from a music licensing service I pay
other people for the rights to use their music and it's much better that way I
don't have any time or interest in composing music currently I do think
that after some time and I've kind of healed the wounds of quitting music I
think I might come back to it and my idea is to actually come back and
possibly compose an album of music to serve as a background for gaming like
maybe do a dungeon music soundtrack and rather than going back to a musical
project actually making some music as black magic craft but I don't know if
and when that will actually happen as a crafting DM do you build terrain to
match the planned encounters or do you plan a session based off the things
you've crafted I don't have a clear answer for that because it is a circle
and it's both so I will often start planning a session and I'll start
thinking about the things that would be good to make for that and I'll make some
stuff and then while I'm making it that'll inspire me to make something
else and then that'll inspire me to change the story and it's kind of a back
and forth it it's both I will say possibly
terrain inspires the story more than the story inspires the terrain when I'm
there's just times when I like want to build something I think it would be neat
and then I'll find a way to work it into a story what's your plan to bring your
craft to the next level and what will you be able to create when you do this
is a tricky thing for me it's actually one of the biggest struggles running
this channel everybody grows over time with their art and ability I have to
keep my growth in check so that it stays viewable and accessible if I wasn't
doing YouTube I don't think I would be building a lot of the stuff the way I'm
still building it I already know that now I have these inclinations where I
just want to sculpt hyper detailed things and then mold them and cast them
and replicate them that way for the channel that's not great it's ok to do
it sometimes and I like to try to interject some videos or some video
series where I'm just doing what I want to do not something that is accessible
and easy but I don't know it's a tricky thing for me because my growth as a an
artist or a builder is definitely affected by and stifled by running this
channel where my main goal is to help people in this hobby start out make it
easy make it approachable so I'm not really sure where it's gonna end up I
think what's probably gonna happen is rather than focusing on ways to make
higher caliber stuff using these different things like sculpting masters
and molding and casting it'll probably just make me better at using the minimal
stuff like still using the approachable materials but doing them better so I
don't know good question though suppose you must spend one year on a small

sushi is my favorite food book no it's been so long that I've had

annoyingly clever and say an empty journal so that I can draw stuff and

I own like thousands of records I can't just pick one I'd probably pick none I

like existing kind of in a bubble and being forced to come up with my own

Billy bookcases for storage I am the worst person to ask about storage in a

to fan quest to show people and that's already stressing me out I understand a

the only person who likes army painter I'm not long time in the Hobby but love

the person asking the question is I don't use army painter just because I

Frost grave was appealing to me a skirmish game in general was appealing
to me because it was more pick-up-and-play there was no planning
and DMing and all that kind of stuff but of all the skirmish games I picked frost
grave because the aesthetics and the setting worked really well with a lot of
the stuff I already had for D&D it was comfortable it was a setting I just was
familiar with I already had a lot of terrain for and the rule system was
pretty simple and the investment was really low I have a whole video

like more details oh and s for convincing know my buddies were pretty
pretty keen to give it a go you've mentioned a few times casually about

a lot more actually right now I'm struggling because I really just want to
keep building stuff in that theme but I don't want to overwhelm the channel with
post-apocalyptic terrain so yes what is the most unexpected challenge and most
unexpected reward you have experienced from going full time as a content
creator well unexpected reward is just simply
the satisfaction of turning something I love and just a passion hobby project
into a legitimate business that successfully supports my family that's
just incredible like it's amazing the biggest challenge I've been facing
there's there's a lot of them one is just dealing with the content that you
always have to be feeding any other job you can take holidays because people
it's a company where you just don't work for a week or two and other people fill
in in your position maybe you have to do a little bit of work ahead of time to
make that happen even small businesses where you're an independent person you
can usually shut down for a week or two to take some holiday
for for me I have my two videos I have to do every week so I can't just stop
and it's hard to keep up to that all the time and yes I know people say well yeah
you just have videos pre-loaded for taking time off and that's fine except
that means that in order to take a week off of work I have to do two weeks worth
of work the week ahead of time so it's not really a true holiday and that I'm
surprising to be more difficult than I anticipated the other big challenge
there's actually the biggest challenge for me is that I spend the majority of
my time not crafting but sitting at a computer editing videos editing photos
doing social media sitting at a computer especially editing I have a really bad
back I've always blamed it on construction and I thought when I
stopped my career in construction that my back problems would get better but in
fact they got significantly worse sitting in a computer chair versus
moving around and doing physical work there's a lot worse on a back which I
mean you know it makes sense when you think about it and there are many days
where I'm sitting there editing a video I am in pain to the point where it's
almost causes me to puke or cry like it bad bad back pain and I have to just
struggle through it and get the video edited I try different things I exercise
I take breaks I try to move around to try to stand up I have a very very very
good computer chair it doesn't matter that's been a real challenge just
sitting down at the desk and editing video when I am in so much pain
it's almost winding so that sometimes what I have to struggle through to get
the videos complete but hey it's my job and it's an awesome job so I struggled
and I fight through it do you have any plans to make builds that are demonic in

to a room tour way harder to do that then I thought because one of the things

it's gonna be really hard to do I'm not sure how to do it I will try to do it

it's actually gonna be hard but essentially I have this room here that's
you know a single car garage sized it's my game room slash crafting room slash
filming space I have my game table in the middle I have my crafting area over
there and then I just have walls of shelving to store
everything and finally getting to set up my own crafting room where should my
emphasis be in creating the room and like organizing and I will say
organization is key one of my favorite things I've ever learned about
organizing workspaces a conclusion I've come to myself but I got the name of it
from Adam Savage which is first-order retrieve ability it's very important
that everything that you use can be grabbed without having to move something
else should be able to open a drawer grab the thing you need go on a shelf
grab the thing you need because when items become buried behind other items
and kind of annoying to get you stop using them I would figure out what the
things are you use the most and keep them all within arm's reach and
accessible and anything that you don't use very often keep it in you know
compartmentalized storage but don't make it so buried that you forget about it
and never see it things they get buried in the back of drawers and boxes they
never get used they just end up getting thrown out three years later when you
reorganize just keep first order retrieve ability in mind that's
difficult in limited spaces but it it's worth the effort to implement it if you
can do you have any tips for crafting in a smaller space tips for how to store
finished work to keep it safe or even just general tips for organizing
crafting materials well some of that was just answered the small space thing is
difficult I'm not the type of person who can do that I would say I'm lucky that I
have this space to be dedicated for what I do but it's not really lucky I just
made the decision to sacrifice space to give that to me now I know you might be
in a one-bedroom apartment and like it doesn't matter if you want a sacrifice
space or not you literally can't or don't have it but in my house my garage
is my game room I live in the city where temperatures often reach minus 40 minus
50 degrees Celsius for large chunks of the year I parked my vehicles outside in
the cold rather than in a nice warm garage
I can have the space I made that sacrifice because crafting a small space
is very difficult for me I have a hard time with it so I'm not the best person
to answer that but I would say having bins or totes that are easy to get stuff
from and pack up so that it doesn't it's not as much of a challenge to set up and
tear down if you can at least get a little area somewhere where you can
leave things set up like if you're painting some minis or building
something just a little place where you can leave it the project set up so that
you're more likely to come back to it that's ideal like even if it's just the
poppier refrigerator you can play stuff maybe have like a little board where you
work on like get a cutting mat put it on a little piece of plywood and keep stuff
set up and place that on top your fridge or slide it under the couch just try to
find one space where you can keep stuff in between crafting sessions so you're
more likely to come back to it because if you have to set everything up and
terabit everything down every time it's going to
discourage you from doing it when you could just sit on the couch and watch TV
so that's all I got hey bro the wall where your paints are stored custom or

inspired to make videos or to do crafting how do you feel when you
would like to relax on the sofa but you have to make a video good question
there's a one of the challenges of this channel is I have to be creative on
demand so one thing to do a creative thing and then share it with the world
as you do it but when it's your job and you have to do it on demand that's very
challenging in it and it takes a particular skill to be able to do that
and it's one that I've slowly learned to develop the end of the day it's my job I
come up with an idea and I make something even if I'm not inspired or I
want to sit on the couch because it's my job the same reason that you have to go
do your job each day despite maybe not being into it that day to work have you
ever considered a crafters build off between crafting community leaders such

do this as their full-time job and do it on the side that would be impossibly
difficult to organize and do it in a way that everyone can fit it into their
